Our domestic media is garbage and anyone quoting the Australian should know they are using a tarted up fox news (literally) In a country where the last person to be re-elected before 2019 and hold a full term as PM was in 2004. Update for passing time. Reducing time spent for forecasting for a while.
Country response to Covid amongst the best globally. However it was only 6 months ago he looked vulnerable due to reaction to fires. This could repeat this winter. Otherwise my score would be lower.

Will Scott Morrison cease to be prime minister before 1 January 2021? Scott Morrison is the current leader of the governing Liberal Party in the Federal Parliament and as such is the Prime Minister.
The Liberal Party selects its leader by a popular vote amongst its members of Parliament and given the three-year electoral cycle there is system of constant campaigning that is exacerbated by media poll findings on a regular basis that determine popularity of the incumbent.
A change of Prime Minister can occur in a matter of three days and has resulted in  7 Prime Ministers in 10 Years.
The job security of a  Prime Minister is dependent on the majority of the Parliamentary party has in place which after the 2019 election is 9 seats.
Morrison suffered a popularity slump due to his lack of actions concerning the severe forest fires experienced during the (Australian) summer but has recovered over his governments efforts to defeat the coronavirus and hold back the resultant unemployment and has the highest approval rating in the last ten years.
He held the unemployment at 7.5% against a projected 11.3% due the jobseeker program and there is media speculation that this program will be extended from the initial September date. Therefore, given his current popularity, his government’s handling of the current issues with the pandemic and China, a leadership spill would possibly be ill-advised and unpopular, his position is potentially safe for the next six months albeit in a volatile job.
https://www.businessinsider.com.au/list-of-australian-prime-ministers-2018-8
https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-8189155/Scott-Morrisons-popularity-surges-amid-coronavirus-crisis-bushfire-PR-disaster.html#comments  https://time.com/5377190/why-australia-changes-prime-ministers/ https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-8500827/Income-support-continue-past-JobKeepers-planned-end-date-says-Scott-Morrison.html  https://www.newstatesman.com/world/australasia/2018/08/why-australia-burns-through-so-many-prime-ministers  https://globalnews.ca/news/4406960/australia-prime-ministers/ https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-52703265

No imminent vote, and as the Guardian puts it "What would normally be toxic and divisive millstones have been mostly waved through by a public that appears to be warming to this new look of collaborative, centrist leadership."

Scott Morrison isn't doing too badly in the polls, and the Liberal party has already gone through the turbulence of replacing a leader recently (leading up to a pretty nerve-wracking election for them)

these days, they will not knife a sitting prime minister in the back (again) due to the ongoing disruptive effects to party alignment and cohesion - though there's still a fair to middling chance he'll fumble something else in 2020 ;)
Strong handling of COVID - everyone has forgotten about the fires
He has regained support through his positive response to the coronavirus pandemic.
no chance, unless he has a heart attack...

He is overweight and in his early 50s - he could die.
Scott Morrison seems to be sitting pretty now. But pandemics and economic distress can cause unforeseen events. So giving a slim chance for him to be removed.
At this point it appears the only way he ceases to be prime minister is death. His approval rating is way up and I can't see him being removed in the next year.

"At the beginning of 2020, Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison was one of the most unpopular people in the country, if not the world. His approval ratings crashed to a lowly 37 percent, perilously close to the point of panic that in recent years has led both the conservative Liberal-National Coalition and the Labor Party to instigate domestic coups against their own leaders...But just five months later, Morrison is now Australia’s most popular prime minister in a decade (there have been five). Newspoll, published by the Australian, shows Morrison has a personal approval rating of 68 percent; other polls show similar high marks. https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/05/05/scott-morrison-is-now-very-popular-australia-he-hasnt-earned-that/

Scott Morrison’s approval rating continues to climb during coronavirus pandemic: https://7news.com.au/politics/scott-morrison/scott-morrisons-approval-rating-continues-to-climb-during-coronavirus-pandemic-c-1000010
ALthough it seems very likely he will still be PM, There is always the possibility of a random event
Covid-19 has increased his approval rating. Another tragic statistic related to covid-19. Likely to still be in job by 1/01/21.
What is the probability of an unrelated scandal?
Poor handling of bush fires, lack of empathy and lack of judgement

With less than 100 deaths from corona so far. And the States and Federal Government on both sides of politics working as a single united group against defending Australia from the virus, and the disaster that is American disunity in the face of clear and present danger, as a comparison for how things could go so badly wrong, Morrison is solidifying his grip on the PM role.

Huge boost in polls from handling of COVID-19 (https://www.google.com/amp/s/amp.theguardian.com/australia-news/2020/apr/07/guardian-essential-poll-coronavirus-response-boosts-scott-morrisons-approval-rating)

Morrison's handling of Cv19 since my last forecast has been consistently well received & he's seen a big surge in support.  I still think that when the next wildfires kick in he may find himself in trouble again because of the negative relationship between those fires & his environmental policies, but because I've bet quite high that he'd go so far, I'm going to have to go back to zero for now and then edge up if the situation changes.

Scott Morrison would have to either be ousted, step down, or die to no longer be prime minister. Dying: the PM is 51 currently. While I could not find very precise odds on this, according to  General Record of Incidence of Mortality, the death rate for the 50-54 age bracket is 0.32%. The odds of the PM dying within the next year are very low, even with COVID19 in the picture. Barring an extraordinary life event or sudden deterioration in health, I do not expect him to stand down.   Ousting is similarly unlikely, as there are now additional barriers against unseating a PM.

This is an update from my previous prediction. Although Prime Minister Morrison was heavily criticized for how he handled the Australian bushfires earlier this year as he was not taking them seriously. And the polls showed the loss of popularity in him from that fiasco.  Now with the Coronavirus epidemic and his countries response being one of the first countries to stop flights from China and calling it a  pandemic even before the World Health Organization did. It seems as if Prime Minister Morrison is stepping up to the leadership role. He has actively addressed his nation many times asking them to stop hoarding materials and saying this is a once in a 100-year crisis and that Australians need to come together. Also, the fact that it isn’t an election year I find it extremely unlikely that they will hold a vote to remove him from office during this crucial time

Sure, Morrison wasn't smooth in the handling of either the coronavirus or the bushfire season, but it seems unlikely that there is actually a change in the prime ministership before elections.

Excluding the Morrison Government, there have been 35 Australian Governments with 30 Australian Prime Ministers from 1901 - 2018 (e.g. Kevin Rudd was Prime Minister for two separate Governments). The incumbent Morrison Government, headed by Prime Minister Scott Morrison, the leader of the Coalition (center right party coalition) and leader of the Liberal Party was formed on 24/08/2018. The number of days from 24/08/2018 to 1/1/2021 is 862 days. Of the previous 35 Governments, 17 have lasted longer than 862 days -
Base Rate - Likelihood an Australian Prime Minister lasting longer than 862 days = 17/35 = .49 = 49% Post 2007, Australian Politics has entered a period of turbulence and uncertainty with Australian Prime Ministers regularly removed due to coups / leadership spills launched against them with no Prime Minister since 2007 completing a full 3 year term.
Prime Minister - Cause of Removal - Length of Government (Days) - Length Greater / Less than 862
2007 - 2010 - Rudd - Coup - 933 - Greater
2010 - 2013 - Gillard - Coup - 1098 - Greater
2013 - 2013 - Rudd - Election Loss - 83 - Less
2013 - 2015 - Abbott - Coup - 727 - Less
2015 - 2018 - Turnbull - Coup - 973 - Greater Despite this turbulence, the likelihood of an Australian Government Australian Prime Minister remaining beyond 862 days has increased - 
X = Updated Base Rate - Likelihood an Australian Prime Minister lasting longer than 862 days = 3/5 = .60 = 60%
Y = 100% - X Y = Likelihood an Australian Prime Minister not lasting longer than 862 days = 40% In reviewing the two occasions a Prime Minister didn't last longer than 862 days, one was due to Election Loss (Rudd) and the other due to a successful Coup (Abbott). A quick glance of previous Prime Ministers shows that these two reasons are the vast majority of a Prime Minister ending. I will account for other potential reasons later.  A = Likelihood an Australian Prime Minister not lasting longer than 862 days due to Election Loss
B = Likelihood an Australian Prime Minister not lasting longer than 862 days due to a Successful Coup A = B (Occur equal number of times in 5 previous Governments)Y = A + B
A = B = 20% (Initial estimates of their likelihood) In relation to B, Morrison in 2018 implemented new rules in the Liberal Party making it far more difficult to launch a successful Coup against a Prime Minister (i.e. Him) by raising the minimum threshold to hold a leadership vote to remove a Prime Minister to 66.7%. Therefore I will reduce the probability of B occurring -
B = 4% = B * 0.2 This has been proven given the Labor Party upon enacting a very similar rule in 2013 hasn't had any Coups since. Y = 24% = A + B
X = 76% = 100% - Y With regard to A, given the severity & nature of the Coronavirus I am very skeptical that an election will be held before 1/1/2021. In addition the Australian economy is expected to enter recession this year, not an ideal condition for seeking reelection in. The next House of Representative Election (Prime Minister sits in the Representative) must happen either before or on 3/09/2022. In the most recent election, held on 18/05/2019, the new Government was sworn in on the 29/05/2019. Assuming a 10 day delay from the election, for the next Government to be sworn in before New Years Eve the election at the latest must take place on 20/12/2020.  Today's date is 28/03/2020. It is 890 days from 3/09/2022 and 268 days from 20/12/2020. A = 30% = 268 / 890 As to whether Morrison wins/loses such an election, I would say 50/50 given Coalition and Labor are the two dominant parties in Australia. Will also reduce by 0.5 the likelihood of an election taking place given the reasons stated above.
A = 7.5% = A * 0.5 * 0.5
Y = 11.5% = A + B
X = 88.5% = 100% - Y With regard to other potential reasons, since 1901 - present, I believe 3 Prime Ministers have died in office, one was fired by the Governor General, one retired and another resigned to join the High Court. Likelihood of next 9 months something similar occurring - 
3.75% = 9 * 6/(2021  - 1901 * 12)
Y = 15% = Y + 3.75% Looking at Scott Morrison personally and the situation in the Liberal Party and Australian Politics -He is youngish at 51 years old, won an election very few people thought possible, described as appealing to both liberal / conservative sides of the Coalition and has recovered in polls after the decline during the bush fires. A potential "Brutus" in Peter Dutton is of limited threat given the rule changes and his limited appeal. Therefore, I believe that the likelihood of Scott Morrison ceasing to be Australian's Prime Minister before 1/1/2021 is 15%.

Even the Australian Guardian are saying Morrison's tone & action on Covid19 are appropriate.  If it looked as though the Covid19 crisis was going to be over within 3 months I'd anticipate another wildfire or other mishandled episode that might sink him, but in the face of existential threat 'strong' leaders tend to do very well, regardless whether their decisions are good or bad.  I still think it's possible another devastating set of fires, poor C19 outcome or other scandal (the sports rort) could unseat him, but the socio-political effects of the pandemic and the likelihood the fallout of this crisis will persist into next year will insulate him from the damage. Morrison rebounded in the latest preferred PM poll to take the lead over Opposition Leader Anthony Albanese.
(Source: https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2020/mar/11/essential-poll-scott-morrison-regains-lead-as-preferred-prime-minister-after-bushfire-backlash) Apart from losing his seat in a General Election or stepping down, the only way he can be ousted is by his own party and, due in part to a string of leadership coups, the Liberals strengthened rules around deposing a leader - now a two-thirds majority of the party caucus is required.
(Source: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-australia-politics-leadership/australian-ruling-party-toughens-rules-on-toppling-leader-idUSKBN1O214W) For the Liberals to do this would be hugely unlikely mainly because Morrison was elected PM less than a year ago in a general election and the Australian people have had five PMs in the last 10 years, with no appetite for a new one.
Assuming Australia continues to function properly.

It looks like his government is doing a good enough job on coronavirus that he will not get tossed out. https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/national/life-returns-to-normal-in-china-as-australia-announces-new-measures-to-stop-coronavirus/news-story/fb3c25dcdad10e59101bceb674b32d38

The Australian people have already suffered huge losses this year.  If they find themselves swamped by an epidemic Morrison hasn't adequately prepared for, and then a second wave of bushfires before the year is out, I can't see him surviving politically in a nation that routinely kicks out mid-term leaders.

Recovery in Morrison's popularity as Australia heads out of bushfires & into coronavirus crisis. Monitoring.

The Prime Minister of Australia Scott Morrison has had to deal with a lot of crises at the beginning of 2020. He had to lead the nation through bushfires in January and now has to deal with the new Corunavirus as well as the economic downturn that is a result of the fears for the virus. Prime Minister Morrison faced harsh criticism from Australians when he took a vacation to Hawaii while Australia was ravaged by horrible bushfires across the country. Also given the fact that there is going to be an economic downturn that is going to hit Australia particularly hard because of the coronavirus. It may seem unlikely that he will continue to be prime minister next year because it is difficult to get reelected if the economy is not doing well and the Hawaii vacation fiasco. However, in a recent poll reported on by The Guardian, his support has not taken a huge downturn as expected. With that being said I think it is unlikely that he will be removed from office unless if his government completely botched the coronavirus outbreak in Australia and the economic downturn that follows it.

Scott Morrison has had a lot on his plate since the start of 2020. From bushfires, government scandals/misappropriation of funds and the recent COVID-19 outbreak it is safe to say Australia hasn't had the best start to the year. And whilst I agree that all these events may not look good for the current government and their current leader, it will be remembered that it was this individual who saw Australia through these unfortunate events. I predict that Scott Morrison will still be the prime minister at the beginning of 2021 and there is a very low chance this will not be the case.

Moderating position in relation to median.  Morrison's handling of the coronavirus & bid to mitigate the impending financial crash haven't been as unfavourably received as his handling of the wildfires & since the virus epidemic may run for months, he has the potential to make up for lost ground & consolidate his position.  Having said that, there's plenty of time along with the potential for more ecological crises, mishandling of the Covid19 outbreak & sports allegations to end his premiership.  Monitoring.
Although Australia often change PMs, the immediacy of the situation seems to have calmed down leaving less pressure on the PM for now.
(OV) Existential threats, like the corona virus, tend to galvanize populations behind their leaders.  Dropping my probability.

After reading up on the news of Australia’s PM Scott Morrison and looking deeper into the percentages of forecasts compared to my first forecast, I have decided that I will increase my percentage ‘yes’. This is initially based on the 5% increase in current consensus- my logic tells me to increase my initial probability by 5% as to proportionally keep with my original logic. The news sources that I read discussed New Zealand’s Jacinda Arden’s anger towards the PM and his handling deportation in Australia. My second source discusses the ways in which PM Morrison has abused the process as being the one permanent member of the cabinet and seemingly covering up key decision-making process leading to further distrust between Morrison and his cabinet and the Australian people as a whole. This forecast will be 18% because I feel more inclined to increase the percentage as i have not seen PM Morrison have a change in pace with public opinion; public opinion is my main form of logic for developing this probability. 
Further analysis will look at the effects of the Coronavirus on his standing.

Australia seems to have gotten closed borders correct w.r.t. coronavirus, reducing some pressure on the PM.
Slight uptick to account for a new landscape in wake of coronavirus disrupting commerce.

Recent Australian PMs have lasted around three years or less. Liberal party has changed leader in the past during a parliament. Morrison has performed very poorly, particularly during the bush/forest fires crisis.
Slight upshift in wake of new corruption claims & calls for Morrison's resignation, with the coalition govt closing down parliament to avoid having to defend him.

Another slight downshift because coronavirus may cause the public to rally round Morrison in a time of external , rather than internal, threat.  There again, a new crisis may dent support for him further if badly managed.
Economic impact of corona virus on Australia, plus a general inability to connect with voters will still not be enough to change the leader that won an 'unwinnable' election

Absence of a popular alternative for opposition to rally around will see Morrison likely to continue for at least another year.  Uncertain global trends are more likely to favour his continued leadership.

Shifting down in light of mixed reactions to Morrisson's Royal Commission report into building resilience to natural disasters.  While climate breakdown is a big and growing issue for Australian voters, the defensive position of 'building resilience' as opposed to slowing climate breakdown via policies that would contradict other Liberal Party & Coalition values may buy him enough time to cling on to the end of the year, depending on interim events.  Report will be published in August.  To be monitored.

I misread the question so I am changing my answer  He is in good health. He has a good parliamentary base. He is reasonably popular and there is little opposition to him. The opposition is fairly ineffectual. So I cannot see why his party would get rid of him.

He is in good health. He has a good parlimentry base. He is reasonably popular and there is little opposition to him. The opposition is fairly ineffectual. So I cannot see why his party would get rid of him.

Since 2007 there have been four spills with the average PM tenure lasting 2.14 years.  The Liberals passed rules to require two-thirds majority to unseat a sitting PM.  This makes a spill less likely and since Morrison has made it 63% of the way towards 1/1/2021 deadline I'm dropping my original baseline forecast by 20%.  The other ways that Morrison can loose his job (defeated in parliament, death, retirement, etc.) all seem unlikely so I'm dropping by another 10%.  These items seem to cover most of my "outside" view by comparing Morrison historically to other PMs.  Next I will start incorporating some "inside view" perspectives.
Australian prime ministers tend not to last long anyway, and Morrison blew it in regards to handling the bushfires, so he will probably be no exception to the short tenure trend.

75% of MPs need to agree to a ballot to remove an Australian PM and Morrison's Coalition currently holds 50.36% of seats.  As of 11th February Morrison was still enjoying 78% approval ratings among Coalition supporters making his removal within the next few months unlikely.  However, since July 2019 Morrison's national approval rating has slumped from 48 to 39% - exactly where Turnbull was four months before his departure in 2018.   Turnbull was ousted at an approval low of 36%, putting Morrison within the frame of vulnerability should a second wave of crises envelop him before memories of the devastation fade.  How likely is such a crisis?  In 2019 Australia suffered a second wave of bushfires beginning in June: part of a warming trend observed since 1910.  Meanwhile Morrison’s policies have done nothing to improve Australia’s ecological stability or resilience to natural, industrial or resource-based catastrophe. With a second wave of fires or other crisis near-certain before the end of 2020, the likelihood of Morrison clinging on into 2021seems proportionately unlikely. UPDATE, 21/02/20:  Came back a day later to re-forecast because 85% seemed rash, but did some more digging & discovered that an Australian National University survey published this week charted the approval rating for Morrison's govt at 27%.  Ominously, the greatest increase in disapproval for new coal mines was among people who'd voted for Morrison's Coalition at the last election (a drop of 15% from 72% in June '19 to 57% in Jan '20), so not only is Morrison in a bad place, policy wise he's doubled down against his own voters.  Theoretically that might leverage the 50% of Coalition MPs now necessary to get rid of him, given the existing pattern of quick turnovers for Australian PMs.
His response to the fire emergency in Australia was pitiful, and his response to future climate effects will be no better.
Yes, because of his climate policy in the face of devastating forest fires and droughts.
The government response to the bush fires is only one problem. My prediction is that the conflict between the natural resources industries and climate change will bring him down
The wildfires have consolidated Australian action regarding climate change and are contrary to Mr. Morrison’s position

A rule change to the Liberal Party's constitution requiring a two-thirds majority of MPs to oust the leader was passed in Dec 2018 and came into force when Morrison returned as PM following the 2019 Australian Federal elections.  https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/dec/03/liberal-party-morrison-changes-rules-to-require-two-thirds-majority-to-unseat-sitting-pm
Although unpopular, he is likely to remain as PM until next election.
He is a populist and will find a way to make himself popular and/or avoid a popular unrest that would lead to his ouster.
While he has faced extreme levels of negative public opinion, Australia has never called an early election due to low favourability.

After reading over some articles and analyzing the forecasts, I am starting with a base probability of 11% that Scott Morrison will cease to be prime minister of Australia. This is because there is a high prediction that Morrison will not be PM based on his current missteps regarding the wildfires in Australia though the data is stilling being accumulated. With this logic and the potential for a leadership spill as the means to remove Morrison, I went with this prediction to start. This prediction has the potential to change as polling data changes and the party's support for Morrison shifts. He began very strong when he took office which informs a lower prediction than the mean though not well enough to inform a percentage lower than 10% at this time.

The Liberal Party is trying to distance itself from its past leadership struggles, especially while their coalition partners appear to have unstable leadership.

Calculated a base rate of the average term of all Australian Prime Ministers, regardless of repeats (3.37 years).  I compared those Prime Minsters with terms above the average to those below the average and calculated and odds ratio.  25 terms were below the average, 10 above. If Morrison makes until 1 Jan 2021 his term will be 2.63 years.  That puts him with those who's terms are less than the average. Base rate: Since 3 December 2007 there have been six prime ministers, including the incumbent Scott Morrison [1]. 3 Dec 2007 - 16 February 2020 (today) is a total of 4458 days. 4458 days/5 changes in PM = average PM tenure of ~892 days. The incumbent Morrison has been in office for a total of 541 days (24 August 2018 - today) so far, and there are 320 days left in this question's time frame. If Morrison is still in office on 1 January 2021, he will have been in office for 861 days - just 31 days short of the average prior tenure length. The base rate implies that if today was 24 August 2018, Morrison would have just slightly under a 50% chance of ceasing to be PM before 1 January 2021. However, given that he has remained in office since 24 August 2018, the base rate will consider the # days left in this question's time frame and the average PM tenure: 320 days left in time frame / average tenure of 892 = final base rate of ~36%  Relevant considerations: Our base rate implies that there is a ~36% of Morrison ceasing to be PM before 1 January 2021 - however, there are relevant considerations that significantly reduce the percent likelihood for this question. In particular, given that a general election has just taken place this past May, the only likely path for Morrison to cease being PM in the given time frame is a leadership spill - essentially, an intra-party challenge to his incumbency. Leadership spills are how four of five of Australia's most recent PM changes occurred, including the last one [2]. In these past leadership spills, only a majority (50%) of a party's vote was required to replace a sitting PM - however, this threshold has recently been raised to two-thirds in the Liberal Party (Morrison's party) for leaders who win an election [3]. Given that Morrison won a general election back in May, his standing is affected by this change. For this reason alone, the probability of Morrison ceasing to be PM should be lowered by perhaps 3/4ths to just 9% (keep in mind that the last leadership spill, for instance, would not have been possible if this rule was in place!). Another relevant consideration is that Morrison's victory in the general election this past May was an upset - he was not expected to win [4]. This fact has probably greatly strengthened his position within the party. However, my guess is that this is cancelled out by recent criticism of Morrison's perceived poor handling of the bushfire situation in Australia, which has caused his approval rating to fall [5]. Thus, we remain at ~9%. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Australia
[2] https://www.economist.com/the-economist-explains/2018/09/04/why-australia-loses-prime-ministers
[3] https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-12-03/liberal-party-passes-leadership-spill-rules/10579172
[4] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/18/world/australia/election-results-scott-morrison.html
[5] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-australia-bushfires/australian-prime-ministers-approval-rating-goes-up-in-flames-idUSKBN1ZB0OU

Lasting through January 1, 2021 implies that Morrison will have been PM for 2 and a half years. Using this wiki article [1] it appears that of the 11 prime ministers since 1970, 8 were in power for longer than 2 and a half years. That metric implies a rate 3/11 ~ 25%. That definitely seems pretty high, but it provides a decent base rate.

Looking more closely at this situation in particular, a PM can be replaced due to  a) death
b) loses an election
c) resignation Since Scott Morrison is 51, the probability of death is about .5% [2]. An election occurs once every 3 years, and since the last election was held in 2019, the only way an election occurs is if there is an early election. So, this question is mainly asking about the likelihood of a vote of an early election and, if so, does the liberal coalition lose. The only way this seems to occur is "A Double dissolution" where the two chambers cannot agree on certain bills. Since, the liberal coalition controls both chambers, this seems highly unlikely to occur. However, there are enough votes in the senate to hold everything up between labor and the other minor parties. So, they could potentially force another election that way.  The current split in the House of Commons and the Senate is very close, with the liberal coalition holding a very slight edge over labor in both. Given that Morrison's approval has fallen and Marles is up, labor may be able to gain significantly by calling an election. However, they would need to convince the minor parties to support them, and I do not know how feasible that is.  Given the complication in calling an election and the potential risk of doing so, I'm going to give this a low probability (10%) of occurring.  @nichodges how does what you suggested relate to the double dissolution? I couldn't find any article relating the two, but they both seem very important to this question. I enjoyed the article and it was very informative. Morrison led a change in the Liberal party rules last year that means a two-thirds majority party-room vote is now required to replace a PM who won an election (a real national one, not a party room one!).[1] This was in reaction to the ridiculous state of affairs where public opinion polls continually freaked out both major parties while in power, causing them to switch leaders mid-term (which required only a majority vote in the party room). Morrison then won an election, so the rule applies to him. He has essentially failed as a leader since the election, but would require a huge misstep to cause a two-thirds majority to boot him out. Particularly given his likely replacement (Dutton) is even less liked by the public. [1] https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/dec/03/liberal-party-morrison-changes-rules-to-require-two-thirds-majority-to-unseat-sitting-pm
